awd_titl_txt: Scaffold-based Biomimetics of Fe-Hydrogenase and Nitrogenase (FeMoco): Interrogating Dynamics, Protein Matrix Effects, and Carbide Motifs
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division, Dr. Michael Rose from University of Texas at Austin investigates the role of scaffold-based ligands and carbides in supporting biomimetic models of the enzymes hydrogenase and nitrogenase. These enzymes catalyze fundamental reactions that underpin living systems in numerous environments. Hydrogenases use dihydrogen (H2) produced by microbiological fermenters to reduce carbon dioxide (CO2) in organisms called methanogens.  Nitrogenases convert atmospheric dinitrogen (N2, which makes up 80% of the air) into ammonia (NH3), which is essential for plant growth. These two chemical reactions are critical to environmental and green chemistry. Studies of the molecular structures and mechanisms of the active sites of these enzymes are critical to the design, synthesis and understanding of earth abundant and sustainable catalysts that will carry out these reactions. This research will be implemented by a diverse pool of undergraduate researchers from UT Austin and REU programs. These students will learn laboratory and computational skills that will prepare them for graduate study and/or STEM careers in. Dr. Rose will continue to focus on raising and improving safety awareness in the Chemistry Department including through his support of the Chemistry Student Safety Organization (CSSO), which promotes best practices in laboratory safety across the Department. The H2fromH2O educational program will continue to operate in local schools and at local events; a hands-on water-splitting experiment delivered through the program emphasizes the importance of renewable fuels and the potential of sunlight-to-hydrogen conversion as an energy paradigm. 

More specifically, this research will investigate the use of supramolecular scaffold ligands based on anthracene and related units that support the chemically complex structure of [Fe]-hydrogenase. This enzyme uses a low-spin Fe(II)-dicarbonyl bound to thiolate, pyridone and organometallic acyl donor to perform H2 activation and hydride transfer. The proposed research aims to discover how molecular flexibility in the scaffold can accelerate H2 activation and catalysis. This will be achieved by installing flexible ‘anthranoids’ such as thianthrene and selenthrene in the scaffold to (i) enable more facile access to strained and reactive ground state geometries, and/or (ii) lower the energy of strained transition states to accelerate catalysis. Secondly, the research will aim to install molecular Fe complexes inside a well-characterized protein scaffold — namely, β-lactoglobulin (βLG). While it has been demonstrated that Fe complexes are catalytically competent, the research will endeavor to enhance catalysis by building structurally well-defined interactions (H-bonding, ion pairs, molecular motion) between the metal site and proteinaceous units. This research also aims to synthesize carbide-based Fe clusters relevant to the nitrogenase active site. Presently there are no known synthetic methods to access iron-sulfur-carbide clusters. The project will utilize ‘historical’ iron-carbide-carbonyl clusters as synthons for sulfur and thiolate incorporation in new Fe model complexes. Both electrophilic (S2Cl2, RS–Cl) and nucleophilic (Na2S, RS–) addition mechanisms will be explored, with an emphasis on using under-coordinated versions (non-Wade-Mingos rules) of the iron-carbide-carbonyl clusters for reactive sulfur addition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This project investigated the structure and bonding of two metal-containing enzymes relevant to chemical energy transformations involving dihydrogen and dinitrogen. The enzyme iron hydrogenase utilizes hydrogen for hydride transfer reactions, while the enzyme nitrogenase fixes dinitrogen from the atmosphere to generate ammonia, the most important nitrogen-containing building block for chemical synthesis and industrial products.

Our small molecule approach to studying these enzymes focused on several key aspects. First, regarding [Fe]-Hydrogenase, we aimed to capture "protein-like motion" in small molecule versions of the enzyme. We reasoned and validated that using dynamic and flexible scaffolds would enhance the reactivity of metal complexes, serving as enzyme mimics due to their protein-like dynamics around the catalytic metal center. Utilizing tricyclic aromatic scaffolds, we demonstrated a three- to ten-fold enhancement in reaction rates for ligand substitution and catalysis reactions.

In a similar vein, we studied how embedding small molecule metal complexes within proteins affects their dynamics and reactivity. Using a model rhenium system and the abundant, cost-effective protein beta-lactoglobulin, we developed a method to bind metal complexes to proteins by employing aliphatic or fatty acid-like chains with low to mid micromolar affinities. This finding represents an important step towards embedding iron-based small molecule catalysts into protein scaffolds in future work, as well as furthering our understanding of the relationship between biological dynamics and reactivity.

Lastly, we focused on carbide-based iron cluster chemistry related to the enzyme nitrogenase. Through our work with organometallic iron carbide carbonyl clusters, we discovered that outer-sphere oxidation generates non-Wade-Mingos (non-PSEPT) intermediates that are amenable to ligand substitution reactions with phosphines, phosphides, and thiolates. This finding serves as a critical entry point towards generating carbide-based iron clusters that mimic the structure and function of the nitrogenase active site, specifically the FeMoCo cluster.

Broader Impacts. In addition to our research contributions, this project provided valuable training to graduate students and a diverse group of undergraduates in inorganic chemistry, synthesis, characterization, and structural analysis. Students enhanced their writing and communication skills and developed technical competencies that will benefit their future careers in industry, postdoctoral appointments, PhD programs, and medical schools. Moreover, our outreach project, titled "H2fromH2O," engaged hundreds of young learners with the renewable energy possibilities of water electrolysis for hydrogen generation, connecting hands-on demonstrations to chemical concepts such as stoichiometry, the ideal gas law, and chemical conversion reactions.


Last Modified: 12/12/2024
Modified by: Michael J Rose

Images (1 of )
  • We hypothesized and validated the installing a dynamic scaffold in place of a rigid scaffold in the synthetic metalloenzyme mimic would engender higher reactivity. The Thianthrene scaffold "flaps" and allows a lower energy transition state geometry, leading to five-times faster rate of catalysis.
    Jordan Labrecque
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Installing "Protein-Like" Dynamics in Small Molecule Bio(metal)mimetics
  • We synthesized and characterized the selenium-based scaffold selenanthrene for possible use as a dynamic scaffold in metal complex ligand design. We devised an "Energetic Flexibility Index" (EFI) to quantify the dynamics and flexibility of possible scaffolds.
    Alec Larson
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Scaffolds flap like a Butterfly
  • Using an outer-sphere oxidant (ferrocenium), we activated the substitution-inert iron-carbide-carbonyl di-anion to stably bind mono-dentate and multi-dentate phosphine ligands. Such reactions and structures are stepping-stones towards synthetic modelling of the carbide-containing FeMoco active site.
    Caitlyn Cobb
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Oxidative Ligation of Phosphines to Iron-Carbide-Carbonyl Clusters
  • We used the common and inexpensive milk protein beta-Lactoglobulin and its fatty-acid binding pocket to dock a model rhenium complex. This represents an important stepping-stone towards studying the dynamics of synthetic metal complexes inside a protein host.
    Emmie Stumbo
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Beta-Lactoglobulin binds Rhenium Complex with C12 Tail
